captions.text:
Yo yo welcome back to Thug Notes.
This week we turning up the heat with
Fahrenheit 451 by Ray Bradbury.

In a bleak-ass depiction of
America’s future, a platinum playa named

Guy Montag be hustling as a fireman. But up
in this hood, firemen don’t put out no fires.

Naw blood. They strapped with hoses to burn
books, cuz them bad boys be straight-up illegal.

After gettin home from the grind,
Montag peeps his 17 year old neighbor Clarisse.

She drops some sick truth that make Montag
question the world’s whack-ass ways. And

talkin to this fox make Guy realize that he
just ain’t happy wit his life.

Then one day Guy gets word that
some old hag been hoardin books, so he gotta

step up and blaze her stash. When he busts
in and starts spittin that venemous kerosene,

he secretly jacks a book and
pockets it. But before his boys can start

smokin her spot, this girl lights a match
and straight burns herself down with her books.
Dayum! Now that’s gangsta.

Next day, Montag’s bossman Beatty
roll up to his crib all unannounced. He starts

mad doggin my boy Montag sayin that if he
be packin books, he better come clean in 24
hours.

But first, Guy wanna know if the answer to
his unhappiness lay in

these books. So he hits up some scrappy english
professor named Faber and learns that the

book he swiped be one of the last known copies
of the bible.

Later Beatty calls Guy out on his sh** and
commands him to burn his

own crib down. Turns out, Montag’s wife
ratted him out. After Guy smokes his own pad,

Beatty tries to arrest him, but BAM- Guy turns
his hose on Beatty and that fool toast.

But before Guy can flee the scene,
a creepy robot dog that the fuzz use to hunt

book lovers shanks Montag as he try to escape.
My man shakes off dat Hound and bails before

the po-po can nab him. As Montag runnin from
the po-lice, he finds that fool Faber, who

tells him where to find a gang of scholarly
hoods who be tryin to preserve the knowledge
of the old world.

Montag finds these playas who say
they dedicated themselves to memorizing books

for when the world is ready for them again.
With parts of the Bible deep in his dome,

Guy joins their ranks and start rollin toward
the city where he gonna help em rebuild society.

Most homies always goin off on how
the main theme of this book is censorship

through book burning. But if you keepin it
gangsta, you know that Bradbury’s main jam
actually be the creation of a mass culture.
As technology got mo legit, the

world got smaller and minority voices got
louder. So to prevent these whiny bitches

from gettin all butt-hurt, a super PC culture
was created to keep any playa from spittin
truth that some homies can’t handle.

But it ain’t only da government
that’s to blame. Naw, bruh. Ray Ray be criticizing

how Americans always jonesin for things to
be simple and positive, even if it all bullsh**.

Peep game at this irony mayne: Most
cats thinkin that with betta technology comes

a more connected society. But on the real,
Braddy-B sayin that just cuz we got the baddest

gear, don’t mean it gonna bring us any closer
to eachother.

My boy Heidegger droppin the same
game in his essay The Thing:

For example, when Mildred ODs and
needs to get her stomach pumped, there be

all kinds of machines all up in her insides,
yet the playas that be operating on her just

don’t give a damn. Like Montag say “Nobody
knows anyone. Strangers come and violate you.”

But don’t be thinkin it’s all bad,
baby cuz it ain’t. Ol Guy is a walking symbol
for the hope of mankind’s rebirth.

See, in German, Montag straight up
means Monday; suggestin that Montag gonna
usher in a new beginning for humanity.

And respect this, son: peeps be
thinkin that the title of the book’s final

section, “Burning Bright,” refernces a
poem by William Blake called “The Tiger”.
Check it-

Just like Blake’s tiger that reppin
both beauty and savagery, dat boy Montag burning

bright as a symbol of both creation and destruction.
Cuz the playa who use to sling fire to burn
books now only blazes with the flame of knowledge.

Look, blood. You just ain’t gettin
it til you peep the dankest motif of this

whole book: the motif of burning. On one hand,
fire be representin the destructive nature

of dis whack society. But it would be straight
up REMISS of yo bitch ass not to think about

how fire also representin the hopeful glow
of the human spirit. Like da light of the

campfire at the end, flame don’t just burn:
it also gives off warmth.

Yo thanks for watching Thug Notes.
Stay fly and hit subscribe.

title: Fahrenheit 451 - Thug Notes Summary and Analysis

comments.author: Garrett Goodfarb

comments.text:
Also Mr. Bradbury was just terrified of technology. Don't forget about 
that. When Montag first meets the robo-hound, he is afraid of it. It's a 
cold, calculated beast. When he is on the run, he fears for his life not 
because of the people but the machine that cares not for reason or 
circumstance, but a completed mission. Bradbury not only stressed the 
importance of not becoming dependent on technology, but that technology 
should be kept in check. Technology should always be for the benefit of 
man, never should it be placed in a position to overtake man.﻿

comments.text: 451 degrees Fahrenheit is the exact temperature at which paper burns.﻿
comments.author: Ian Snuffleupagus

comments.text:
+Ian Snuffleupagus That's not really true. There are a lot of different 
ways that something can catch fire (auto-ignition and piloted ignition 
being two noted ways) and a lot of different factors that play into what 
temperature actually causes an ignition. There's a lot of different 
standards to determine when something catches fire and each will give a 
different result, and even within tests using the same standards things 
just catch fire at different temperatures. The universe is simply too messy 
to say with certainty that paper burns at 451.

comments.author: Source90000

comments.text:
+John Bullock I'd say most Americans saw the blatant ignorance in a society 
that wouldn't know any better, since the information they receive is 
secondhand anyway. For instance, in the firehouse, there is crest with the 
rules of The Firemen of America. Benjamin Franklin is listed as the 
organization's first fireman, in 1790.
Now for the reader, this would be considered true which is meant to reflect 
the level of ignorance maintained by a government that bans reading of 
books and is free to revise history as they please. No one reading this 
could have actually known by 1790, Benjamin Franklin was 84 years old and 
on his deathbed. Nor could they have known that this founding father was a 
fireman who prevented fires, not in the 1790s but in the 1730s.
With this example, its clear to me that something reputable and real as a 
book is not to be treated lightly. Even in Brave New World, the Bible was 
stowed away from the eyes of society because it was decided "unnecessary," 
"confusing," and "obsolete." The message is that we are able to know so 
much, but only if we are willing (As is said by Granger by the novels end).
comments.author: Brent Wiggins

comments.text:
+Brent Wiggins I feel that if you are critiquing American society, subtlety 
is luxury few authors can afford.  The fact that this is a classic book 
that is taught again and again and yet has had almost no true social impact 
almost proves it was too subtle for most Americans

comments.author: Brent Wiggins

comments.text:
I do consider some of the ideas, like how people watch more television than 
reading books, impressive. However, the problem stems from the way it was 
written and Guy Montag's character. I understand why its considered a 
classic, but I just didn't enjoy it looking back to it.
comments.author: Source90000

comments.text:
Its humanistic approach, super science as an efficacious means for bad 
(nuclear war, Red Scare) instead of good, and loss of self through the 
regression of technology rather than progression itself meant something 
from the time of its publication and ever since then. If you ask me, Montag 
must be the most subtle of most characters in the novel, if not him then 
Faber. It's a precautionary tale about the developments we further grasp 
too, which aren't as cautiously making us aware of the potential danger 
their may be as we tag along for the bandwagon.

Ray Bradbury gave an example with TV; it's brainwash in most regards. 
Reality TV shows garner more people's attention in their homes then does 
the actual people together in that home. Clarisse reminds us that the 
smaller details aren't insignificant. Having human interaction, sharing 
emotions and opinions are what makes us involved and alive, not some screen 
with a few disembodied heads passing as "your family." They are the things 
in life we sometimes pay no notice to or lose sight of because of the next 
big thing or some trend or fad. Being aware of the world around you is the 
most important lesson I take away from Fahrenheit 451. Books are another 
example of the world around you; without these ideas from all around the 
world, there'd be no concern for happiness, just some gimmick that you're 
told is happiness.
comments.author: Brent Wiggins

comments.text: Fire also illuminates...﻿
comments.author: freshPrincess626

comments.text:
That was a great point about Bradbury fearing overall hyper-PC culture 
instead of just him against censorship. I never would have thought of that

comments.author: Matthew Franklin

comments.text:
The motif of "burning" doesn't go deep enough. This video ignores the fact 
(twice) that the city burns at the end of the novel. The camp fire is not 
the last fire, the burning city is. Fire is used in the end of the novel in 
a way more indicative of sanitation. The city, and with it Montag's 
troubles with the law, are sanitized by the bombs and the fire. This leaves 
the door open for the scholars to rebuild with their books. This fits more 
closely with the allegory of the Phoenix that Bradbury so beautifully 
articulates at the end. Analysis isn't always about "making a good point". 
It's also about connecting the dots that link each motif that help drive 
the story.﻿
comments.author: TheRossMadness

Also, Communism.﻿

comments.author: Adam Miller

comments.text:
+TheRossMadness I agree with you but the powers that be in F451 certainly 
encouraged the apathy and lack of depth by eliminating science and math 
from the schools, lowering the age for pre-k, removing front porches from 
community housing plans, raising speed limits and quickly disposing of the 
dead. Keep everyone busy and distracted with bullshit information that 
means nothing and they'll never have enough time to consider just how 
meaningless their existences are.  Make them consume consume consume...an 
earlier poster mentioned sarcastically how not subtle the book seemed but 
I'd argue that we are just at the point where it is too hard to ignore how 
unlike the people in MOntag's world are to us.  Bradbury also said, 
"There's more than one way to burn a book."  I teach in Houston ISD at an 
almost 100% Title I school and daily I see the kids metaphorically burning 
books and it is disgusting and tragic.
comments.author: Amanda McDonald

comments.text:
Incorrect. Simply choosing two stories set in a dystopia does not "get this 
book". The preservation of the Bible is not key to Fahrenheit 451 (as it is 
in Book of Eli), in fact in the Coda to Fahrenheit 451, Bradbury states 
that he didn't choose the Bible specifically, it was just something in his 
head. Also, Equilibrium is oppression through chemical means. Fahrenheit 
451 is largely a willing disregard on the part of the people to further 
themselves. The Firemen are more of a facilitator of that willingness. In 
fact, the citizens in Fahrenheit thrive off of emotion instead of the lack 
thereof. Sometimes books are worth reading, just like movies are worth 
watching.
comments.author: TheRossMadness

comments.text:
I love this book! It's so true, the growing concerns about our future 
adults and our products our running world. It's sad when no one teaches the 
things that are truly of human design, that can stand the test of time. 
Things that come from the best of us, should be taught in the best way. The 
human way, with comprehension, passion, and feel. I love learning, asking 
question, solving problems, it makes me feel on top of the world. I think, 
a golden world would be a world where people taught, learn, and teach, so 
the progression of the human race may never ever stop. Thank you for making 
me pick up this book. I can't rely on public schools and I never want to. 
  ﻿

comments.author: Mario Barraza

comments.text:
Also, this videos are really supposed to just whet your appetite.  If you 
think this video is great, it is.  But it's just a snack, and if you really 
get into the books they talk about, each one is an intellectual feast.  And 
once you read them, you are part of that tradition.  
So just ask yourself: Would you rather have a side order of nachos and 
cheese at Taco Bell, or go to the Las Vegas all-you-can-eat Buffet?
